passages.title: The Yellow Wallpaper (Excerpt)
passages.text:
I sometimes fancy that in my condition if I had less opposition and more society and stimulus — but John says the very worst thing I can do is to think about my condition, and I confess it always makes me feel bad.

So I will let it alone and talk about the house. The most beautiful place! It is quite alone, standing well back from the road, quite three miles from the village. It makes me think of English places that you read about, for there are hedges and walls and gates that lock, and lots of separate little houses for the gardeners and people.

There is a delicious garden! I never saw such a garden — large and shady, full of box-bordered paths. I should hate it if John and I had it for the summer. He is very careful and loving, and hardly lets me stir without special direction. I have a schedule for each hour of the day; he takes all care from me, and so I feel basely ungrateful not to value it more.

passages.title: Ozymandias
passages.text:
I met a traveller from an antique land,
Who said — "Two vast and trunkless legs of stone
Stand in the desert. . . . Near them, on the sand,
Half sunk a shattered visage lies, whose frown,
And wrinkled lip, and sneer of cold command,
Tell that its sculptor well those passions read
Which yet survive, stamped on these lifeless things,
The hand that mocked them, and the heart that fed;
And on the pedestal, these words appear:
My name is Ozymandias, King of Kings;
Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair!
Nothing beside remains. Round the decay
Of that colossal Wreck, boundless and bare
The lone and level sands stretch far away."

passages.title: The Open Window
passages.text:
"My aunt will be down presently, Mr. Nuttel," said a very self-possessed young lady of fifteen; "in the meantime you must try and put up with me."

Framton Nuttel endeavoured to say the correct something which should duly flatter the niece of the moment without unduly discounting the aunt that was to come. Privately he doubted more than ever whether these formal visits on a succession of total strangers would do much towards helping the nerve cure which he was supposed to be undergoing.

"Do you know many of the people round here?" asked the niece, when she judged that they had had sufficient silent communion.

"Hardly a soul," said Framton. "My sister was staying here, at the rectory, you know, some four years ago, and she gave me letters of introduction to some of the people here."

He made the last statement in a tone of distinct regret.

passages.title: The Road Not Taken
passages.text:
Two roads diverged in a yellow wood,
And sorry I could not travel both
And be one traveler, long I stood
And looked down one as far as I could
To where it bent in the undergrowth;

Then took the other, as just as fair,
And having perhaps the better claim,
Because it was grassy and wanted wear;
Though as for that the passing there
Had worn them really about the same,

And both that morning equally lay
In leaves no step had trodden black.
Oh, I kept the first for another day!
Yet knowing how way leads on to way,
I doubted if I should ever come back.

I shall be telling this with a sigh
Somewhere ages and ages hence:
Two roads diverged in a wood, and I—
I took the one less traveled by,
And that has made all the difference.

passages.title: Still I Rise
passages.text:
You may write me down in history
With your bitter, twisted lies,
You may tread me in the very dirt
But still, like dust, I'll rise.

Does my sassiness upset you?
Why are you beset with gloom?
'Cause I walk like I've got oil wells
Pumping in my living room.

Just like moons and like suns,
With the certainty of tides,
Just like hopes springing high,
Still I'll rise.

Did you want to see me broken?
Bowed head and lowered eyes?
Shoulders falling down like teardrops,
Weakened by my soulful cries?

Out of the huts of history's shame
I rise
Up from a past that's rooted in pain
I rise
I'm a black ocean, leaping and wide,
Welling and swelling I bear in the tide.

Leaving behind nights of terror and fear
I rise
Into a daybreak that's wondrously clear
I rise
Bringing the gifts that my ancestors gave,
I am the dream and the hope of the slave.
I rise
I rise
I rise.

passages.title: Harlem (Dream Deferred)
passages.text:
What happens to a dream deferred?

Does it dry up
like a raisin in the sun?
Or fester like a sore—
And then run?
Does it stink like rotten meat?
Or crust and sugar over—
like a syrupy sweet?

Maybe it just sags
like a heavy load.

Or does it explode?

questions.questionText: What contradiction in the narrator's feelings suggests she may not fully trust her own perspective?

choices.label: A
choices.text: She describes the garden as delicious but says she hates it

choices.label: B
choices.text: She calls John careful and loving, yet feels controlled by his schedule

choices.label: C
choices.text: She says the house is beautiful but complains about its distance from the village

choices.label: D
choices.text: She enjoys writing but refuses to talk about her condition

questions.explanation: The narrator simultaneously praises John as 'careful and loving' while revealing he 'hardly lets me stir without special direction' and dictates her schedule. This tension between her stated gratitude and described confinement reveals an unreliable self-assessment shaped by her disempowered position.

questions.questionText: Which statement best captures the central irony of "Ozymandias"?

choices.label: A
choices.text: The traveller never actually visited the desert himself

choices.label: B
choices.text: The sculptor created a work more enduring than the king's empire

choices.label: C
choices.text: The king's boast of eternal power is surrounded by nothing but empty desert

choices.label: D
choices.text: The poem is told secondhand, making its truth uncertain

questions.explanation: The central irony is that Ozymandias commanded others to 'Look on my Works... and despair!' yet 'Nothing beside remains' — the inscription demanding awe at his power sits amid total desolation, undercutting its own message and illustrating the impermanence of earthly power.

questions.questionText: How does the narrator's description of the house and garden function rhetorically in the passage?

choices.label: A
choices.text: It establishes the setting as a gothic horror location

choices.label: B
choices.text: It serves as a displacement — discussing surroundings to avoid confronting her condition

choices.label: C
choices.text: It demonstrates her keen observational skills as a writer

choices.label: D
choices.text: It foreshadows the eventual decay of the property

questions.explanation: The narrator explicitly states 'So I will let it alone and talk about the house' — pivoting from her forbidden self-reflection to detailed environmental description. This rhetorical displacement reveals how John's prohibition against thinking about her condition redirects her analytical energy toward her surroundings.

questions.questionText: In "Ozymandias," the phrase "The hand that mocked them, and the heart that fed" most likely refers to:

choices.label: A
choices.text: The traveller who discovered the ruins and the king who built them

choices.label: B
choices.text: The sculptor's skill in capturing the king's expressions, and the king's passions that inspired them

choices.label: C
choices.text: Death's hand that destroyed the statue and the desert that consumed it

choices.label: D
choices.text: The poet's craft and the reader's emotional response

questions.explanation: 'The hand that mocked them' refers to the sculptor's hand that imitated (mocked = copied) the king's passions in stone, while 'the heart that fed' refers to the king's heart that nourished those commanding passions. The sculptor's art outlasted the king's power — the passions 'yet survive' only because of artistic representation.

questions.questionText: Based on the passage, which word best describes Framton Nuttel's state of mind?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Enthusiastic

choices.label: B
choices.text: Anxious and uncomfortable

choices.label: C
choices.text: Curious and engaged

choices.label: D
choices.text: Angry and resentful

questions.explanation: Framton is undergoing a 'nerve cure,' doubts whether visiting strangers will help, struggles to make appropriate conversation, and mentions knowing 'hardly a soul' with 'distinct regret.' These details collectively portray a man who is socially anxious and ill at ease.

questions.questionText: Saki's choice to describe the niece as 'very self-possessed' while Framton 'endeavoured to say the correct something' establishes what narrative dynamic?

choices.label: A
choices.text: A conflict between youth and old age

choices.label: B
choices.text: A power imbalance where the young niece controls the social interaction

choices.label: C
choices.text: A mutual respect between host and guest

choices.label: D
choices.text: An unreliable narrator who misreads social cues

questions.explanation: The contrast between the niece's composed self-possession and Framton's awkward striving to say the right thing immediately establishes her as the one in control. This power imbalance — unusual given their age difference — sets up the reader's expectation that the niece will manipulate the situation.

questions.questionText: The passage from "The Yellow Wallpaper" most directly critiques which societal practice?

choices.label: A
choices.text: The isolation of rural communities from urban centers

choices.label: B
choices.text: The medical establishment's suppression of women's autonomy under the guise of care

choices.label: C
choices.text: The upper class's obsession with maintaining grand estates

choices.label: D
choices.text: The dangers of writing as a form of self-expression

questions.explanation: The narrator is forbidden from thinking about her condition, given a strict schedule, and 'hardly let to stir' — all framed as John's loving medical care. The passage critiques how 19th-century medicine (specifically the 'rest cure') used the authority of male physicians to restrict women's intellectual and physical freedom while presenting control as benevolence.

questions.questionText: The final image of "lone and level sands stretch far away" primarily creates a sense of:

choices.label: A
choices.text: Adventure and exploration

choices.label: B
choices.text: Peaceful solitude

choices.label: C
choices.text: Vast, indifferent emptiness

choices.label: D
choices.text: Natural beauty and wonder

questions.explanation: The 'lone and level sands' stretching 'far away' evoke an infinite, featureless expanse that is utterly indifferent to the fallen monument. The words 'lone,' 'level,' 'boundless,' and 'bare' accumulate to create a powerful sense of emptiness that dwarfs human ambition.

questions.questionText: The central irony of "The Road Not Taken" is that:

choices.label: A
choices.text: The speaker never actually chose between the two roads

choices.label: B
choices.text: The speaker claims to have taken the less traveled road, though both were 'really about the same'

choices.label: C
choices.text: The speaker regrets the choice immediately after making it

choices.label: D
choices.text: The yellow wood prevents the speaker from seeing either road clearly

questions.explanation: The speaker observes that both roads 'equally lay' and were 'worn... really about the same,' yet concludes by claiming 'I took the one less traveled by, / And that has made all the difference.' This contradiction reveals how people retrospectively construct narratives about their choices being more significant than they actually were.

questions.questionText: In 'The Road Not Taken,' the phrase 'knowing how way leads on to way' most directly suggests:

choices.label: A
choices.text: The speaker's awareness that one choice leads to another, making return impossible

choices.label: B
choices.text: The speaker's belief that all paths eventually converge

choices.label: C
choices.text: The speaker's confidence in making the right decision

choices.label: D
choices.text: The speaker's preference for exploration over commitment

questions.explanation: The speaker recognizes that each choice opens new paths while foreclosing others — 'way leads on to way' captures how decisions cascade forward, making it impossible to return and try the alternative. This understanding motivates the speaker's doubt about ever coming back to the first road.

questions.questionText: In 'Still I Rise,' the simile 'like dust, I'll rise' primarily emphasizes:

choices.label: A
choices.text: The speaker's fragility and vulnerability

choices.label: B
choices.text: The speaker's inevitable resilience despite attempts to suppress her

choices.label: C
choices.text: The speaker's desire to disappear

choices.label: D
choices.text: The speaker's connection to the earth

questions.explanation: Dust, when trodden down, inevitably rises back up — it cannot be permanently suppressed. This simile establishes the speaker's unstoppable resilience: even when 'tread[den] in the very dirt,' she will rise again, just as dust naturally does.

questions.questionText: The repeated rhetorical questions throughout 'Still I Rise' (such as 'Does my sassiness upset you?') primarily function to:

choices.label: A
choices.text: Express genuine confusion about the oppressor's motivations

choices.label: B
choices.text: Challenge and mock the oppressor while asserting the speaker's power

choices.label: C
choices.text: Request permission to continue rising

choices.label: D
choices.text: Apologize for causing discomfort

questions.explanation: The rhetorical questions are confident and defiant, not seeking actual answers. They taunt the oppressor ('Why are you beset with gloom?'), highlighting the speaker's awareness that her confidence and success disturb those who wish to see her 'broken.' This questioning technique asserts power while mocking those who oppose her.

questions.questionText: The line 'I am the dream and the hope of the slave' connects the speaker's personal resilience to:

choices.label: A
choices.text: A specific historical event from the Civil War

choices.label: B
choices.text: The collective aspirations and survival of African Americans across generations

choices.label: C
choices.text: The speaker's family history exclusively

choices.label: D
choices.text: A rejection of the past in favor of the future

questions.explanation: By declaring herself 'the dream and the hope of the slave,' the speaker positions her personal triumph as the fulfillment of her ancestors' aspirations. The phrase 'gifts that my ancestors gave' reinforces that her rising is not individual but carries forward the resilience and dreams of enslaved people throughout history.

questions.questionText: In 'Harlem,' the series of similes (raisin, sore, rotten meat, syrupy sweet) creates what overall effect?

choices.label: A
choices.text: A celebration of diversity and variety

choices.label: B
choices.text: A progression from mild decay to dangerous festering

choices.label: C
choices.text: A sense of natural cycles and renewal

choices.label: D
choices.text: An appreciation for simple pleasures

questions.explanation: The similes progress from drying up (passive decay) to festering and stinking (active corruption), building tension toward potential explosion. Each image becomes more visceral and unpleasant, suggesting that deferred dreams don't simply fade — they intensify and potentially become dangerous.

questions.questionText: The final line 'Or does it explode?' differs from the preceding lines by:

choices.label: A
choices.text: Being the only line that doesn't use a simile

choices.label: B
choices.text: Suggesting violent action rather than passive decay

choices.label: C
choices.text: Offering a positive resolution to the deferred dream

choices.label: D
choices.text: Returning to the opening question without development

questions.explanation: While previous images describe passive deterioration (drying, sagging, festering), 'explode' introduces active, violent potential. Standing alone as a single question, this line suggests that deferred dreams may not simply decay quietly but could erupt in social upheaval — a particularly resonant warning in the context of the Civil Rights era.

questions.questionText: The opening line 'What happens to a dream deferred?' functions as:

choices.label: A
choices.text: A rhetorical question that the poem explores through multiple scenarios

choices.label: B
choices.text: A direct question requiring a single definitive answer

choices.label: C
choices.text: An expression of personal confusion

choices.label: D
choices.text: A celebration of delayed gratification

questions.explanation: The opening question frames the entire poem's structure. Rather than answering directly, Hughes explores multiple possibilities through vivid similes, each offering a different potential outcome. The question format invites readers to consider the various fates of postponed dreams rather than settling on one answer.

questions.questionText: The phrase 'I shall be telling this with a sigh / Somewhere ages and ages hence' reveals that the speaker:

choices.label: A
choices.text: Will regret the choice for the rest of their life

choices.label: B
choices.text: Recognizes they will construct a meaningful narrative about the choice in hindsight

choices.label: C
choices.text: Plans to return to the fork in the road

choices.label: D
choices.text: Is confident they made the objectively correct decision

questions.explanation: The speaker anticipates telling this story 'with a sigh' in the distant future, self-aware that they will retrospectively frame the choice as significant ('made all the difference') even though the roads were actually equivalent. This reveals understanding of how humans narrativize their past to create meaning.
